page.title: 19Local History
page.content: {Roman Fortress. The remains of a Roman Fortress burial ground and pottery kilns,lie near the church at Gelligaer.The site was excavated by James Ward 1899-1913,for the Cardiff Naturalist Society.Drawings and photographs are included in a Rhymney Valley publication"Gelligaer Roman Fort." {A Norman Church. The church of St.Catwg was first written of in a Papal"bull"in 1119 AD. A cross discovered on the site of a Celtic church to the north of Gelligaer village,is now kept in the church.The parish stocks dating back to 1376,are also preserved there.A baptistry there is a relic of Cromwells Puritan church.Earliest religous activity in the area is marked by a stone,known as"Maen Catwg" -a prehistoric stone connected{(cont.)
